Will you please do it my way? You'll  get into trouble if you don't. If  anybody talks to you, tell them... I  do not speak English.
(indignant) I do not speak English.

Right. In Omaha the driver will put  you on the bus for Salt Lake City  and the new driver will take... (bends back second  portion of ticket) ...this part. When you get to Salt  Lake City, ask the driver, 'Las Vegas,  please'...
(impatient) 'Las Vegas, please. I do not speak  English.' What is hitchhike?
You want this ticket?
Yes.
Then don't be smart.
Last call for bus 33 to Vermillion,  Sioux City and Omaha... loading at  Gate 3.
That's your bus. (picks up the map and  folds it) When you get to Las Vegas, ask the  driver. 'Lathrop Wells, please. I do  not speak English.'
(falling into step  next to her) 'Lathrop Wells, please. I do not  speak English.'

(hands him the map) You keep this. Now this is hitch- hike... (stops in the middle  of the waiting area  to illustrate) You stand on the side of the road,  the highway... you understand? And  you face the cars going in the  direction you want to go. When you  see a car or a truck coming, you  stick out your thumb like this...
Jenny takes a few sweeps at an imaginary highway with her thumb. The stares this pantomime draws make the STAR MAN  more nervous about the bus trip than he already is.
Your thumb tells the driver that you  want a ride.
The car will stop?
(continuing toward  the loading platform) Not every car, but... a car will  stop... Maybe not the first car...  maybe number eight, number fifteen...
The STAR MAN stops.
When do I get to Lathrop Wells?
Tomorrow morning. Start hitch-hiking  right away and...
Jenny pushes open a glass door to:
...you'll have plenty of time to get  to where you want to go.
The STAR MAN hangs back when he sees the security guards.
Don't worry. They're not going to  hurt you. Come on. (gives him ticket) Only show this to the driver. Nobody  else. And don't lose it.
Can I have the gun?
No.
She maneuvers him into the end of the line.
You might need this.
She takes some of the paper money out of her wallet and s it in his pocket.
Don't be afraid. Do what I told you  and you'll be okay.
(nervous) Yes.
The line moves forward a step.
Well... I'm going to go now.
Go?
Yes. I have a long ride ahead of  me... (takes his hand) Goodbye.
Goodbye.
He watches her walk away.
Jennyhaydn.
Yes?
Please stay.
Jenny comes back and takes his hand.
I'll stay till you get on the bus.

A family of four climbs aboard and the line moves up. The STAR MAN is alert to everything happening on the platform Jenny sneaks him an affectionate look. No one in front of him has baggage to check and they move quickly past the D until the STAR MAN is next in line.
Ticket?
The STAR MAN hands the Driver his ticket. The Driver rips out the first coupon and hands it back.
See? You're going to be okay.
When they stop at the door, she impulsively kisses him on the cheek.
Goodbye.
(touches his cheek) What?
It's a kiss... (she motions for him  to get on the bus) Goodbye...
Let's go.

The STAR MAN climbs the steps just ahead of him. The door closes. Its ENGINE REVVING, the bus backs out of its stal Jenny catches a glimpse of the STAR MAN bent over in the  aisle looking out at her. She waves until the bus rounds building.
Jenny's green Mustang loops around the end of a row of ca and heads for the street.
LOOKING OVER Jenny's SHOULDER, we SEE the Star Man waitin for her at the curb.
(softly) Oh no...
She stops next to him and rolls down her window.
What happened?
I was afraid.
Jenny moans and lays her head on the vinyl of the window  sill. When she raises up, he smiles at her.
Okay, you win. Get in.
Shermin is standing next to the security guard in the mid of a knot of shouting people.
This kind of thing's real bad for  business...
He couldn't even speak English.
Those kind of people should be shot.
What happened?
I think he was just lost...
Who's side are you on?
No way he was going to get away from  me.
We move in on a lapel mike pinned to the front of Shermin shirt.
The hubbub in the shopping center is being recorded on a  tape deck. Lyman, a phone to his ear, is seated in front the television screens.
Where's that?... And it was one  person, one way...

He hangs up and heads for the rear door. Jenny Haydn's cu Visa statement occupies the upper left screen. The last t items are circled: The charge for the Greyhound ticket an the credit for the return of that ticket.
The security guard tags Shermin into the parking lot.
Eyewitnesses are the worst. You get  two of them together. You got three  stories. You know what I mean?
Shermin sees Lyman come out of the crowd surrounding the  police cars in front of the helicopter.
Is there a reward in this?
Huh?... Eh... no, there isn't
Because I'm the one who called the  police, you know.
Yeah, thanks. We appreciate that.
Hey, it's none of my business why  you're chasing a retard... You want  my opinion, it's the girl. She had  to hold the guy's hand all the way  to the car like he was a kid.
You saw that?
Hey... he didn't look like no big  time criminal to me.
Lyman meets them. It is obvious he has something to tell  Shermin.
Eh... the store tells you to call  when there's trouble, so they won't  get sued... But that shouldn't matter  if there's a reward, right?
I wouldn't think so.
(peeling off) That's what I thought. So remember  it was me because sometimes rewards  come late, you know.
We will. (he turns to Lyman) Something's wrong here. She's helping  him now.
(alarmed) I know. She bought him a ticket for  Lathrop Wells and put him on the  bus. He didn't stay on though and  they drove off together.
(shaking his head) Doesn't make sense.
Maybe he's turned her into one of  them. They enter the crowd around  the helicopter.
The Mustang cruises along between fields of corn.
Why did your ship land on this  planet... on Earth?
It was a mistake.

The following conversation will be played over various vi of Americana: a station wagon load of kids, waving and  laughing, lovers kissing at a bus stop, billboards, car l a dog taking a leak against a tree, cheerleaders practici on a football field, a funeral cortege, a telephone repai up on a pole.
You thought we were a different  planet?!
No. My ship was doing a map of all  the suns and...
Stars... When a sun is far away, we  call it a 'star.'

We were doing a map of the stars and  all the other things up there when  we saw a small ship. My... eh... we  kidnapped it. On it there was a map  that said how to come to Earth. This  was very important. Before then, we  thought we were the only people in  all the stars.
You did? That's funny. So did we.
Yes?
Yes.

We told our home, and the people who  tell us what to do on my planet said  to come and look but not to talk,  not to land, not to shoot. Just to  look from up there. We came and...  the driver of my ship...
The captain...
The captain wanted to land to see  close and to get some things from  Earth to take home. The police came  and shot at us. One of the people  from my ship was killed.
Oh, that's terrible. I'm sorry. Was  he a good friend?
I don't understand 'friend.'
A friend is a person that is good to  you... someone you like to be with...  someone you like to laugh with...
He was a good friend... The captain  took the ship away fast and I was  not in the ship.
The police shouldn't have started  shooting. But you can hardly blame  them. You surprised them. They didn't  know you were up there. When they  saw you, they thought you were here  to hurt us.
I understand.
Sounds like your captain's going to  get hell when he gets back home.
What is hell?
It's bad.
He will.
Pause. Jenny feels the STAR MAN staring at her. She turns look at him. His gaze doesn't waver. She looks back at th road, then back at the STAR MAN.
What are you doing?
Are you my friend?
Yes.
(smiles) I am your friend.
Jenny's Mustang is whipping west out of Lincoln, Nebraska We HEAR A JUMBLE OF RADIO STATIONS as the SELECTOR is RUN THROUGH THE FREQUENCIES.
Jenny is driving. The STAR MAN finds a RELIGIOUS STATION the RADIO.
(on radio) God is your creator. God is your  master. God is you savior. God is  the only reason that you exist. If  God...
(during the above) Who is God?
Jenny is tired. She doesn't want to get into that.
Nobody knows.
Why?
I don't know.
The STAR MAN lets it drop and finds a COUNTRY AND WESTERN STATION.
I like this music.
I've noticed... Do you understand  what they're saying?

Jenny smiles at him, then:
Do you have music up there?
Yes.

I do not want to.
Don't be afraid... I'd really like  to hear it.
She TURNS OFF the RADIO.
Please.

He turns away from her, clears his throat and begins. His singing is like nothing we have ever heard. Vibrations of tones and glottal stops blend into a haunting, seductive  fugue. The STAR MAN stops.
I am not a good singer.

With the STAR MAN's SERENADE WAFTING over the Nebraska pl we FALL BACK TO FIND a Highway Patrol car tagging along a safe distance behind the Mustang.

Drawn by the bright colors on their covers, the STAR MAN  wanders over to the magazine rack. By chance, he selects copy of 'Playgirl' and begins to look through it.
You have one with two beds?
Sure.
I'll take that.
(slides her a  registration card) Fill this out. (as Jenny writes) Will this be cash or credit card?
Credit card.

(digging through her  purse) We're only going to be here a few  hours...

Jenny, look...
From behind the STAR MAN, we WATCH Jenny react to the ope Playgirl centerfold that he is holding up.
Put that back.
But I have never seen this before. I  am not complete.
Although we cannot see it, we know what he is pointing at
Put it back.

The STAR MAN swivels the picture around so that he can se it. Jenny hands the smirking Clerk her credit card. He st to the side and inserts it into the imprinter. Out of the corner of his eye, he sees a dot of light leave the STAR  MAN's forehead to drop behind the magazine and into his  trousers. You can park your car in front of  the room.
He drops the key on the counter.
Through his side window, the DRIVER can see the motel off
(into microphone of  his radio) What did these two do?
All anybody knows is that they're  armed and dangerous.
In the office, he can see Jenny and the STAR MAN leave th counter and head for the door. He raises a pair of binocu to his eyes for a good head-on look at them.
We SEE Jenny and the STAR MAN come out of the motel offic
The Second Officer lowers the glasses and looks down at t telex pictures of Jenny and the STAR MAN taped to the  dashboard.
Be a piece of cake for us to take  'em.
THROUGH the WINDSHIELD, we can SEE Jenny and the STAR MAN approaching the Mustang.
National Security folks should be  here any minute. Let them take care  of it. That's what they get the big  bucks for.
I want a drink. May I have two  quarters?
At the passenger door, Jenny sets her purse on the car ro to take out her wallet.
(handing it to him) You shouldn't drink so much of that  stuff. It's bad for you.
On the radio they say it's good.
Hurry up.

Over her purse she notices the patrol car facing her from the restaurant parking lot. There is certainly nothing un about a patrol car in a restaurant parking lot. She shrug it off and gets in the Mustang.

Jenny's behind hasn't even hit the seat before she sees t patrol car parked on the frontage road off to her left. S looks at the STAR MAN. He's busy pounding on the drink  machine. She turns around to check the lot behind her and spots the patrol car there.
(coming to the car  with a drink can in  each hand) The machine gave me two. Should I  put one back?
No. Get in.
(rounding the hood) You can have one.
(as he gets in) I'm not sleepy anymore. Let's drive  for a little while longer.
The STAR MAN stiffens when he sees the patrol car on the  frontage road.
Are you angry at me?
No. I'm just not tired. Let's go.
The Mustang moves toward the frontage road.
(as the Mustang rolls  onto the frontage  road) They made us. Let's get 'em.
All three patrol cars jam on their rack lights and, with  their SIRENS HOWLING, peel out after Jenny and the STAR M
At the SOUND, the STAR MAN snaps his attention to the rea view mirror. It's ablaze with police lights. He tromps on the gas.
No.
Shermin is patched into the Nebraska Highway Patrol and i listening to the pursuit.

The Mustang careens down the on-ramp and squeezes into th traffic a hair's breath ahead of an 18-wheeler. This cuts off the patrol cars momentarily, but the Mustang doesn't  have the speed to stay ahead of them. Using the other car on the road as shields, the STAR MAN dodges from lane to  lane trying to keep the police from coming alongside.
The lead patrol car feints forward on the STAR MAN's side The STAR MAN sways over to cut it off and the middle patr car slips in next to Jenny. The STAR MAN grabs the gun fr under the seat.
No!!! No!!!
He's got a gun!!
Jenny screams. A shotgun blast from the middle patrol car rips through t door and into Jenny. Part of the FRONT WINDOW is BLOWN OU Bleeding badly, she slumps against the STAR MAN.
Jennyhaydn! Jennyhaydn!!

Her eyelids flutter open and she tries to speak, but can' The middle patrol car is lining up for another shot. The  STAR MAN slams the Mustang into it, sending it spinning o the shoulder and into a ditch. The last patrol car speeds up to replace it. The lead pat car slips in next to the STAR MAN. They've got him in a  sandwich. The STAR MAN stands on his brakes.
Caught by surprise, the patrol cars rocket ahead of him. Mustang cuts across the swatch of land that acts as a cen divider in the highway and races west in the eastbound la
The STAR MAN squints against the headlights of the on-com traffic as he calmly wedges his way straight through it.

The lead patrol car tries to follow him but is clipped by Cadillac swerving to avoid the STAR MAN and bounced back  into the center divider. The last patrol car parallels th Mustang in the westbound lanes.
The STAR MAN realizes he's still boxed in. A car carrier  swerves by on his left. The lane behind is open. The STAR MAN takes advantage of the opportunity.
The Mustang vaults off the shoulder of the highway into a open field and bullets away through the weeds. The rush of oncoming traffic traps the three patrol cars the center divider.

Jenny moans as the car jostles over the rough ground. The STAR MAN puts out a hand to cushion her ride. His headlig pick up a gravel road splitting the field and he turns on it. In a quick look back, he sees the patrol car shooting across the highway after him.

We FOLLOW the Mustang as it winds upward through the graz lands sparsely dotted with clumps of trees. The plume of  dust kicked up by the fleeing car is turned silver by a f moon. The WAIL OF the PATROL CARS is DISTANT BUT CLOSING.

The Mustang barrels around a curve and slides to a surpri stop before a gate in a barbed wire fence that ends the r With the .45 in his hand, the STAR MAN jumps out of the c and tries the gate. It is locked. When he turns back to the car, he sees something that  frightens him more than the approaching patrol cars. A  helicopter has joined the chase. He looks for a place to  hide. A stand of cottonwood and elm fifty yards on the ot side of the gate offers the only protection. The STAR MAN opens the passenger door. Jenny is soaked in her own blood. He hooks the strap of her purse over his  shoulder, lifts her tenderly and, cradling her in his arm wiggles between a fence post and the gate and jogs into t trees.
The helicopter sets down behind the Mustang. Shermin lead Bell, Lyman and the technicians to the car.
(seeing the blood on  the passenger seat) One of them must be pretty badly  hurt.
Shermin pushes the seat forward. The STAR MAN's life-supp suit is stuffed in the space behind it. The patrol cars s around the curve.
(to Bell, indicating  the suit) Get this back to the copter.
Shermin takes a bullhorn from Lyman and goes around to th front of the Mustang. The highway patrolmen get out of th cars behind him.
(bullhorn to woods) Mrs. Haydn, please come out. We don't  want to hurt you or your friend.  Please put down your weapon and come  out.
Jenny's limp weight is beginning to slow the STAR MAN. He hears the bullhorn but doesn't stop.
Shermin lowers the bullhorn and speaks to the patrolmen.
Okay, fan out. These people have a  gun but we want them alive.  Understand?

A deep shadow on the other side of an elm offers a likely hiding place. He moves through the underbrush toward it.  Without warning, his feet begin to slip out from under hi He struggles to regain his balance. When he does he looks down to find himself staring at a R RIVER 150 feet below. The bank on the other side is just few feet above the water and in the moonlight he can see flat plain cut by a highway that stretches into the dista Slowly, he backs away from the edge of the cliff. From under the elm he watches the helicopter sweep out ov the ravine. Its searchlight darts toward him bleaching th treeline. The overhanging branches cloak him and Jenny an the light passes without picking them up. The STAR MAN ad his grip on Jenny and starts off in the opposite directio from the helicopter to look for a way down the cliff.

Shermin, his people and the patrolmen are combing the woo with flashlights in a picketline search. The Third Driver stops at the mouth of a clearing that runs between the  cottonwood and elm to the cliff. He takes a bite off a bl of chewing tobacco. As he replaces it in his pocket, he sees a shadow flit ac the far end of the clearing. He swings his flashlight in  that direction. The beam catches a piece of Jenny and the STAR MAN.
Over here! They're over here!
Standing on the rim of the gorge, the STAR MAN sees the r of his pursuers' flashlights choking off any possible esc He eases Jenny to the ground behind a boulder. She whimpe with the pain.
(strokes her cheek) You will be all right.
He stretches over the top of the boulder and scatters FOU SHOTS at the lights.
The patrolmen, the technicians and Shermin all hit the gr and kill their lights.
Mrs. Haydn, we don't want to hurt  you. Put down your gun and come out.  We just want to talk to your friend.

The STAR MAN peers around the boulder. At that instant th searchlight from the helicopter happens to splash across men in the field. He sees that their guns are drawn and  pointed in his direction. The STAR MAN pulls back and tak a marble from his pouch. It grows and glows gold as the S MAN rolls it between his palms. When it reaches the size a baseball, he clutches it firmly in his right hand and  EMPTIES the .45 toward Shermin and the police. This time, there is a BARRAGE OF ANSWERING FIRE. With the BULLETS RICOCHETING around him, the STAR MAN lif Jenny to his shoulder. He massages the golden orb until i becomes the size of a soccer ball, then takes two quick s to the edge of the cliff and leaps into the abyss.

The upward thrust of the ball supports their fall and und its glow they begin a slow descent to the other side of t river. Above them, the helicopter dips back and locks its searchlight on the shelf of boulders they just left.

The STAR MAN sets down with the smoothness of a man stepp off an escalator. He looks over his shoulder. The helicop is still concentrating its spotlight on the ridge. He spe to the ball in his language.
(subtitles) Iron channel message. Almost caught  by pursuers. This may hinder escape.  Wait for me.
He lets the ball go and, with even more velocity than the others, it zips into the sky.
A WOMAN in a Frederick's of Hollywood negligee lets a TRU DRIVER out of one of the Winnebagos parked to the side of the main building.
Don't forget to tell the boys where  you had a good time.
(calling back to her) You weren't that good.

Her rusty laugh follows him into the parking lot. He walk between the trucks to a semi which has half of a pre-fab  mobile home tied onto its flat-bed. The polyethylene that covers the open side of the house flaps in the WIND at th lower corner next to the cab. The Driver opens his door. takes out a staple gun and refastens the dark green plast to the house frame.
In the middle of the empty bedroom, the STAR MAN tries to cushion Jenny against the sudden JOLTS made by the semi a it lumbers out of the parking lot.
With the Driver taking it smoothly through the gears, the semi picks up speed.

The STAR MAN moves Jenny into a rectangle of moonlight sh on the floor by a high, wide window and strips off her bl The cold light marbles Jenny's skin and makes the blood f her wounds appear black. With her blouse, the STAR MAN wi away the blood on the right side of her head and neck. He finds a deep glass cut on her cheek and two entry points her neck. He concentrates on her cheek and we can SEE the glow of his brain through his human skin. A bit of the white light comes out of his forehead. It tu across to Jenny's cheek and settles into the wound. The S MAN watches intently as one end of the wound flares brigh for an instant, then dies. The flesh left behind has been closed without a scar. A larger piece of light drops out of his forehead into wh left of the gash. With that area suffused in a healing gl he shifts his focus to the pellet holes on her neck. He s two pieces of light plunging into the wounds. Immediately they spread into halos which we can SEE radiating from un the skin. Out of the night comes a LONG BLAST ON the AIR HORN and t STAR MAN has to steady Jenny as the truck swerves around  something in the highway. When it settles back into its ride, the STAR MAN wipes th blood off Jenny's shoulder. The beams of the passing cars through the plastic catch the fatigue on the STAR MAN's f as he works over Jenny.
With its pre-fab house, the semi rumbles through Julesbur Sterling and Ft. Morgan. By the time it gets to Denver, d is beginning to color the tips of the Rocky Mountains.

It's still dark in here. With a chunk of light in his lef hand, the STAR MAN dabs at the last of Jenny's wounds, le behind a phosphorescent bandage. More of these patches gl up and down her right side. He checks her over to see if  he's missed a wound. He hasn't. He covers her with his windbreaker and, exhausted by his  efforts, sits back against the wall. He waits to see that Jenny is sleeping comfortably, then presses the palms of hands together. The satel compass appears between them. T green dot tells him he is still on course.

Colorado Highway PATROLMEN are dropping orange fluorescen cones across two of the three westbound lanes to form a  roadblock. The sound of a harmonica draws us to Shermin's helicopter parked in a meadow beside the road.
As the radio technician plays the harmonica, Lyman clangs down the steps and bends to wake Shermin who is sacked ou under the fuselage.
Tell him I'm not here.
I did.
Shermin sighs and rolls over on his back. He looks terrib
Get me a radio. At least I won't  have to look at his face.
Shermin is holding a field radio to his ear.
We're growing very concerned back  here. There's no use pretending  otherwise. We're rapidly approaching  a 'condition red.' People are  beginning to ask difficult questions.
I'll make this as simple as I can,  George. They disappeared.
I don't care where you're from you  just can't disappear into thin air.
(through a punchy  hysterical laugh) George, listen to what you're saying.  This thing's changed itself into a  man. Disappearing may not be that  big a deal.
So far you've let it cross the heart  of America. For two days it has been  absorbing information that is  detrimental to our security. I don't  see the humor in that.
Stung, Shermin takes a deep breath, controls himself and  returns the radio to his ear.
Maybe... look, this is just something  to think about... from what I got at  the shopping center, it was more  scared than anything else... I don't  feel it's as big a threat as you  think it is...
Is that what's affecting your  performance?

I'm not being unpatriotic, and I'm  doing my damndest to catch them.  Bell's up on 80 and I'm down here on  70 past Grand Junction. They're  heading west. If they're not flying  we have a damn good chance of getting  them. All I'm asking is that you  people think about it.
You just do your job, Shermin. We'll  make the policy.
The semi is in the slow lane. Its right rear turn signal  blinks steadily telling US that it is leaving the highway and going north at the intersection ahead.

Jenny stirs awake under the windbreaker in the bedroom as sloppy DOWNSHIFT JOLTS the house. Her eyes flutter open a she looks around the room trying to figure out where she The truck leans into the turn. Jenny braces herself on on arm and sits up. Catching the windbreaker as it slips off her front, she  remembers that she was shot and examines her right side. runs her fingers over her cheek and neck, across her shou and down her side, feeling for traces of the wounds she k she sustained. She has been completely healed and there a no scars. She leans forward and looks down the hallway.
Hello... hello.

The WIND snapping the polyethylene is the only answer she gets. She picks her blouse off the floor next to her purs but throws it aside and shrugs into the windbreaker when sees the blood and bullet holes. Her sudden rise to a standing position makes her light-he and she has to lean against the doorway until the spinnin stops. With her hands outstretched, as guards against the sway of the truck, Jenny shuffles down the hallway.
Hello. Where are you?

There is no one in the kitchen and she continues into the living room. It is empty. Jenny opens the door to an encl back porch. It is also empty. The STAR MAN is gone. She  returns to the living room and stands there not really kn what to do next. The countryside rushes by outside a floo to-ceiling picture window. A WAIL FROM the semi's AIR HORN jars Jenny out of her rev and she goes to press her cheek against the window. She i looking past her left hand at the road when she notices a wide green ring on her finger above her wedding band. She steps back from the window to examine it, then with some  trepidation, twists it off. As it clears the end of her  finger, the STAR MAN's VOICE SPEAKS OUT OF IT.
Jennyhay...

Jenny drops the ring as if she'd been stung. The STAR MAN voice stops as soon as she does and the ring bounces acro the floor until it hits the baseboard. It looks innocent  enough lying there, but Jenny has a great deal of trouble making herself approach it. When she finally picks it up, it does nothing. She turns in her hand and when the side of the ring hole that was f her when she took the ring off faces her again, the STAR  MAN's VOICE CONTINUES.
...nd. You are all fixed. I'm sorry  you were shot. I was a big problem  for you. Thank you for your help. I  can go to my ship alone now.
The semi is picking up speed as it heads north.
The Driver checks his side view mirror to see if the lane next to him is clear and is astonished to see a woman's a sticking out of the polyethylene waving a blouse at him.
Smoke billows from under the tires as the semi skids to a stop.
Jenny, her purse over her shoulder, is running toward the cab as the Driver steps out with a wrench in his hand.
Where did you stop last?
What the hell do you think you're  doing?
Where did you stop last?
Stay right there...
What was your last stop?
Elmo's...
Where's that?
About five miles back.
Jenny's thumb is already out for a ride as she sprints ac the highway.
(shouting after her) Are there any more in there?
A passing car TAKES US TO the STAR MAN as he runs along t shoulder to a maroon and white '57 Chevy that has pulled to pick him up.
A swarthy, bald MAN with hairy arms leans across the seat
Where are you going?
Las Vegas, please. I do not speak  English.
Hop in.
(re-entering the flow  of traffic) I can only take you to Grand Junction,  but you'll have a better chance to  get a ride from there.
The STAR MAN smiles.
Where you from?
The STAR MAN starts to point to the sky, then catches him
I don't understand.
Parlez vous Francais?... Habla  Ingles?... Sprechen zie deutsch?
These are foreign words to the STAR MAN and he pastes on smile.
Good job, neither do I. What do you  do for a living?
(pretending) I don't understand.
I'm a cook. Do you understand 'cook?'
No.
Food. Eat. I prepare food. I work as  a cook. That's how I make money.
I understand.
What do you do?
(searches for an  answer, then) I make maps.
Hey, that sounds interesting. You  like it?
Eh... yes.
Make any money?
No.
(takes a pack of Camels  out of his pocket) You don't get rich as a cook, either,  believe me. I got a girl going to  college this fall. The wife had to  go back to nursing to help pay for  it.
He sticks a cigarette in his mouth and flips one up for t STAR MAN.
Smoke?

The STAR MAN takes it, quickly examines it, then position it in his mouth at the exact angle the Cook did. His eyeb raise when the Cook flicks his Bic and puffs an ash on th end of his cigarette. The butane flame is swung in his direction and he flinche back before allowing the Cook to singe his Camel. He copi the Cook's puffing and the end of his cigarette begins to glow.
She wants to become a doctor. She's  a bright kid. Hard worker. I think  she'll make it. But the damned  inflation's driven the tuition up so  high it makes it real tough on a  family like ours.

The Cook inhales deeply from his cigarette and blows smok at the windshield. The STAR MAN mimics the inhalation, th chokes. His eyes bulge and his cheeks puff out as he trie to be cool and not cough. The Cook takes no notice of his struggles.
I got two other kids. I don't know  what we'll do when they get old enough  for college.
Smoke starts to dribble out of the Star Man's nose and mo Puzzled, he re-examines his cigarette.

Everybody blames it on the oil crisis.  That might be where it starts. But I  think a lot of people are just using  that as an excuse to rip the rest of  us off. I see it every day in the  kitchen. Peaches. We use the gallon  cans. The price has gone up three  times in the last year. And now the  cans are only half full.
The Cook takes another drag. As if etiquette required it, the STAR MAN hurries to copy him. This time there are no effects.
Do you have children?
No.
They're damned expensive and a pain  in the ass sometimes, but I wouldn't  trade having them for anything.
The Cook flicks his ash out of the window. A moment later the STAR MAN mirrors his action.
What do you think of America?
It is beautiful.
A truck stop set back as little as the law allows from th BUZZ OF INTERSTATE 70.
I'm looking for a guy about this  tall, with brown hair and really  gray eyes...
We FIND Jenny at the set of fuel pumps nearest the highwa dogging an ATTENDANT while he services an 18-wheeler
He had on tan cords, a plaid shirt  and a baseball cap... probably  hitchhiking.
I don't pay much attention to those  guys.
(taking out her wallet) In the last hour or so...
Nope.
Jenny folds back the plastic windows to the picture of he husband.
This is him.
(shakes his head) Sorry.

We FOLLOW Jenny as she wends her way through the trucks  questioning other attendants. The RUMBLE OF TRAFFIC DROWN OUT their CONVERSATION, but the answer is always the same Finally, we FOLLOW the picture as Jenny hands it up to an ATTENDANT cleaning the windshield on a Peterbilt cab.
(looking at picture) I don't know... I'm not sure. I might  have seen him up the road a piece on  my way in. He's long gone by now.

He hands the snapshot back to Jenny. She nods a 'thank yo and looks wistfully around the yard. There is nothing she can do. Fitting the picture back into her wallet, she wal away. After a few steps she turns back.
You know if anybody here's going to  Wisconsin?
Ask inside.
It's bustling, loud and smoky. Jenny is standing just ins the entrance. She licks her lips and tries to clear the f out of her throat.
(small voice) Anybody going to...
Nobody pays any attention to her. Her voice trails off. S swallows hard and tries again, this time booming out.
Anybody going to Wisconsin?
The activity in the diner comes to a screeching halt and the silence Jenny adds in a normal voice:
I need a ride.
An OLDER MAN, with a face seamed by cigarettes and weathe waves at her from the counter.
I'm going to Des Moines. If you can  wait till I finish here, you're  welcome to ride along.
This gets some good-humored cheers and catcalls.
I can wait.

Smiling self-consciously, she takes a seat at the end of counter and orders coffee from the waitress. While she is waiting for it to come, she happens to glance outside and sees a Colorado Highway patrol car stopped in the yard. The officer on the passenger side is talking to one of th attendants. Jenny turns away from the window and finds th she is able to watch the conversation in a strip of mirro that runs around the top of the pie case. The squad car l and her coffee arrives.
(to the waitress) Where's the phone?
Jenny drops a dime in the slot and dials 'O.'
Operator... may I help you?
Could you give me the highway patrol,  please?
After TWO RINGS, the phone is picked up on the other end the line.
Sergeant Packert, Highway Patrol.
My name's Jenny Haydn. I think you're  looking for me. I was kidnapped in  Eau Claire, Wisconsin a couple of  days ago. But I'm free now.
What was your name again?
Jenny Haydn. I'm on my way home and  I don't want anybody I'm with shot  at when you...
Hold on.

Standing back of the officers, Shermin watches them check cars passing through the squeeze point. Every car trunk i opened. Vans and campers are looked into. Lyman runs up and whispers in Shermin's ear. Shermin is  startled by what he hears. He leaves Lyman in charge and  hurries to the helicopter parked in the field beside the  roadblock.
A TECHNICIAN gives Shermin a headset phone as he enters.
(hand over the mouth- piece) You trace it yet?
All we know right now is that it's  east of here.
Shermin puts on the headset and the technician starts a t recorder.
This is Marc Shermin. Where are you,  Mrs. Haydn?
I don't know. Someplace called Elmo's.  Look, I just wanted to tell you that  I'm all right and I'm on my way home.
You've been through quite an ordeal,  Mrs. Haydn. Why don't you stay where  you are and let us pick you up? We'll  fly you home.
No. You'll want to ask a lot of  questions I don't want to answer  right now. I already have a ride.
The Technician hands Shermin a note which reads: ELMO"S T STOP/ABOUT 30 MILES EAST.
I only called to tell you I was free  and not to shoot anybody I was with  if you see me.
Shermin jabs his thumb upward, indicating that the helico should lift off.
Is the man who kidnapped you there  now?
I told you. He let me go. I'm on my  way home.
(his hand over the  mouthpiece) Get a highway patrol unit over there.
Shermin's helicopter lifts off.
Mrs. Haydn, I'm going to have to ask  you to stay where you are.
A sharp rap on the glass startles Jenny and she turns aro to see her ride.
Ready?
Jenny holds up a finger that asks for a moment longer on phone.
(into phone) Mr... I'm sorry, what was your name  again?
Marc Shermin.
Mr. Shermin, I'm hanging up now. If  you want to ask me any questions,  call me at home in a couple of days.  I'm in the book.
Do you know what you were kidnapped  by?
Pause.
Mrs. Haydn...
He doesn't want to hurt anybody.  Please leave him alone.
Is he on his way to Lathrop Wells?
This hits Jenny like a kick in the stomach. She leans her head back against the wall. Her ride is pacing outside th booth.
What's he planning to do in Lathrop  Wells? Is he meeting someone there?
Jenny smashes the receiver back in its cradle and throws  open the door.
(on her way past the  weathered driver) I changed my mind. Thanks.
She rushes down the hallway to the dining area where agai she stands just inside the entrance.
(at the top of her  lungs) It's me again...
The place goes quiet except for a smattering of laughter.
I need a fast ride west.

The speedometer reads 90. The driver, a bespectacled, pim faced SIXTEEN YEAR OLD, shifts into fifth gear. Jenny is  harnessed in the passenger seat. Chatter from a CB under dash COMPETES WITH ROCK N' ROLL ON THE TAPE DECK.
You sure this is your car?
(with a stutter) My grandmother's rich.
(as they come up on a  station wagon) Slow down, slow down.
Geez, Mrs. Haydn, we just got going.
But he downshifts. The Porsche is going a mere 80 when th pass the station wagon.
(peering at its  occupants) I told you I'm looking for someone.
In the cars, too?!
I don't know where he is.
This is going to be a real drag. I  thought you wanted to go fast.
Howling at full throttle, three highway patrol cars rush  past them in the opposite direction. Jenny swivels around follow their progress until they are out of sight.
They after you?
What? No, of course not.
(his stutter thicker  than before) Would be kinda neat if they were. I  think I could outrun them. Maybe get  my picture in the papers.
Jenny takes a second look at this guy. He flashes her a g toothed grin.
The Cook's '57 Chevy makes a left on the street intersect the off-ramp and stops at the curb. Behind it a large pla yellow chicken twirls on a pole above the restaurant it  advertises.
Well, here we are... You go down  that ramp there, you're sure to get  a ride.
(getting out) Thank you.
And don't be shy about your English.  You speak better than a lot of people  I know. (leaving) Take care of yourself.

As an afterthought, the STAR MAN duplicates the Cook's wa then heads down the ramp. As he clears the frame, our VIE ZOOMS AND ZOOMS AND ZOOMS UNTIL we can SEE a piece of the roadblock in the valley below him. During the MOVE-IN, we BEGIN TO PICK UP CB CHATTER.

Flash for all you good buddies heading  west on 70. Smoky's got a roadblock  just beyond Grand Junction... Better  dump your dope, they're going through  everything... He's right. I was just  there and I'm still sore...
Jenny TURNS DOWN the ROCK 'N ROLL to listen to the CB.
Ah loves to be frisked! What are  they looking for? I'm holding. Any  way around it? Where are you? Oh  no!! There it is!!
I bet you we find your friend at the  roadblock.
Jenny doesn't answer immediately. She takes her time chec out the people in a VW they are passing.
(to the road ahead) We better find him before that.

In the style prescribed by Jenny, the STAR MAN raises his thumb to a dilapidated Vega shimmying down the on-ramp. T two blue-haired ladies inside are afraid to look at him a they go by. He has the same luck with an attractive blond secretary that passes on the highway.
A highway PATROLMAN is standing behind the open door of h car speaking into the mike of his radio.
The girl's not here, Mr. Shermin.  Seems right after she talked to you,  she got a ride west with a kid.
All six TV screens display the road rushing under it.
(into mouthpiece of  his headset) You get that, Lyman?
We're ready.
Shermin's S65 banks through a U-turn and chases west.
A dun-colored Roadrunner gurgles down the ramp and stops front of the STAR MAN. Two grubby LONG HAIRS in worn west clothes are inside with boxes of house-hold utensils and  duffle bags.
Where you going?
Las Vegas, please.
We're going to L.A.
He looks at his buddy stretched on the jumble in the back The buddy nods.
Sure. Get in. We can drop you in  Vegas or get you darn close.
The STAR MAN opens the door and gets in.

The CB CONTINUES TO CRACKLE with news of the roadblock.  Jenny's eyes restlessly search the overpass under the whi yellow chicken for any sign of the STAR MAN. She sees the dun-colored Roadrunner waiting at the foot of the on-ramp for a break in the traffic, but she is too far away to se who's inside. As the Porsche gets closer, it overtakes an wheeler and Jenny's view of the Roadrunner is cut off  entirely. She passes without seeing the STAR MAN.
The Porsche weaves through the traffic giving Jenny a cha to look into the cars and trucks it shoots by.
Jenny is turned around looking back at a camper.
I'm telling you, you're going to  find him at the roadblock, or right  after, or not at all.
If he didn't want to go through the  roadblock, is there any other way to  get to Vegas?
Fly.
Jenny gives him a withering look.
The five-fifty. We already passed  it. But it'll take him way out of  his way.
Pull over. I've got to get back there.
Why wouldn't he want to go through  the roadblock?... What did you guys  do?... I won't tell anybody.
It's easier not to tell if you don't  know.
The Porsche slows to a stop on the shoulder.
(as Jenny opens the  door) Wait. Could I have your autograph?
Sure.
She leans back and gives the startled Teenager a kiss on mouth, then gets out.
I have nothing to do. I'd like to  help you.
Don't worry. I'll be all right.

She closes the door. The Teenager takes a last look at he before pulling back on the highway. Jenny waits for a car the slow lane to go by, then runs across to the line and  waits for cars in the fast lane to go by.

The STAR MAN spots Jenny standing on the line peering int the on-coming cars for signs of him. He becomes agitated his mouth begins to move soundlessly. There is a break in the traffic and Jenny dashes to the center divider. The S MAN leans across his driver and yells as the Roadrunner  plunges by her.
JENNYHAYDN!!!

Jenny spins around to see the Roadrunner skid to a stop o the shoulder and the STAR MAN get out. A motorcycle bombs by. He starts across the lanes of traffic toward Jenny. A truck blasts past him in the slow lane. He is buffeted in the fast lane. Jenny runs down the center divider to meet him. A VW honks, its tires squeal on the pavement as it  swerves around him. He reaches the safety of the center  divider. Jenny throws her arms around him and lays her he against his chest. He stands there uncomfortably not know how to respond to this human emotion.
I told you goodbye. Why are you here?
The police are waiting for you up  ahead. There's a roadblock. You have  to go back.
This car will take me to Las Vegas.  I cannot go back.
The police know about Lathrop Wells.  We have to go another way. Come on.
She grabs his wrist but he hangs back.
If I don't meet the ship, my people  will go home without me.
Please understand. If you go this  way, you'll never get to your ship.  The police know about Lathrop Wells.  We have to go another way. I'll get  you to your ship. I promise.
I will go. But not you.
You shit! I'll decide if I go or  not. Not you. I don't know what you  do on your planet, but I didn't think  that was very nice walking out on me  like you did.
I don't want you to be hurt.
Come on.
Holding the STAR MAN's hand, Jenny pulls him toward the r
I didn't ask to come along on this  trip, but I sure as hell am going to  be the one to say when I get off.

They bolt across the lanes of traffic to the other side o the road where she flags down an old black pickup truck. says something to the driver and she and the STAR MAN cli into the back. As the truck returns to the highway, the C OF AN APPROACHING HELICOPTER OVERPOWERS the TRAFFIC SOUND
Shermin's helicopter slices around a pine-dotted peak  following the twists of Interstate 70 below. In the near  distance, we can SEE the roadblock.
Unnoticed by Shermin or the Technicians, the black pickup passes off the television screens carrying their quarry e
(into headset) Any sign of either of them yet?
The roadblock appears on the television screens.
Lyman, wearing a headset plugged into a belt pack, is wal down the line of cars.
I don't think they're going to show.
A swift kick from Shermin sends a stool clanging into a  bulkhead. The Technicians won't meet his eyes when he tur back to them.
Okay. Tell the highway patrol to  block all major arteries off 70 from  here to Elmo's.
Two highway patrol cars scatter the traffic in front of t with their rack lights and SIRENS.

Jenny and the STAR MAN are sitting against the cab, a hor blanket drawn up around their shoulders. They can see the flashing lights coming from way down the road and watch  helplessly as the patrol cars eat up the distance between them.
The pickup makes the turn onto Highway 550.

For a moment, Jenny and the STAR MAN think they're safe.  That hope turns to despair when the two patrol cars loop  after them. They keep getting closer. The STAR MAN inches the blanket up over his nose. Unexpectedly, the patrol ca are thrown into a skid. When they stop, they are facing e other ready to inspect the traffic coming off 70. They lo the blanket from their faces. Jenny lays her head back ag the cab, exhausted.
The Cook said I speak good English.

A RUMBLE OF DISTANT THUNDER follows the lightning that fl from the dark clouds hanging on the horizon. Looking  incomplete without its trailer, the tractor/cab of a Mack truck makes a turn on a farm road, revealing Jenny and th STAR MAN standing on the gravel. The STAR MAN looks back where they came from. There is nothing coming so he sets in the other direction.
Where are you going?
I must meet my ship.
Why can't we wait here for a ride?
I feel better if I move.
We're hundreds of miles from where  you have to be.
The STAR MAN ignores her and continues to walk.
(shouts at him) Even if we walk five miles, it's not  going to make any difference.
Jenny turns toward an oncoming car and sticks out her thu The STAR MAN falls into the same pose just back of her. T car honks at them as it breezes by.
(screams after it) Asshole!!
(shocked) Where did you learn that?
The cook.
A torrential rainstorm lashes the countryside. The STAR M and Jenny splash along the edge of the asphalt. Their hea are lowered against the weather. They are both drenched t the skin.
(after a few steps) We're not going to get a ride tonight.
I can't stay on this planet.
No one's traveling in this weather.
You promised you would get me to my  ship.
(shouts after him) I will. I will. We still have another  day.
You promised.
What do you want from me? There are  no cars on this road. I didn't ask  for this stupid storm.
The STAR MAN mutters in his language.
What are you saying?
You can stop. I will go on alone.
We're too far away to walk. Don't  you understand?

The STAR MAN looks at her. With the rain streaming off hi face, he looks at her. For the first time, the reality of the situation hits him. He turns and, swearing in his own language, flails at the rain. A distance from Jenny, he s and cries out in English.
I can't stay here. I want to go home.  I don't want this skin. I don't want  to look like this.
Jenny can see him standing with his head bowed. She walks over to him.
(trying to ease his  pain) Why don't you send one of your radio  balloons and tell your captain that  you might be late?
I used the last one to jump off the  cliff...
Let's find a place out of the rain.  I'm sure we'll get a ride in the  morning.
I can't be late. I don't know if the  radio balloons work above your planet.  I don't know if my words went to the  ship. If I'm not there, the captain  will think I'm dead and go.
We'll get a ride in the morning.
A flash of lightning shows us:
Jenny and the STAR MAN are following the tracks to an  abandoned boxcar.
The STAR MAN climbs in and pulls Jenny after him. Jenny i shivering badly.
Can you close the door?

The STAR MAN scrapes it forward. He activates the satel  compass which lights the interior of the boxcar. While he doing this Jenny turns her back to him and takes off her  jacket. Her teeth chattering, she tries to wring the wate out of it.
You are cold.
You're damn right I am.
I do not get cold.
Clutching the windbreaker to her breasts, Jenny looks at STAR MAN over her shoulder. It doesn't take her long to m up her mind.
(crossing to him) Open your shirt.

She waits while he struggles with the buttons. After two brushes away his hands and undoes the rest. She lets the  windbreaker drop and, slipping her arms around his waist, presses her bare chest against his.
(savoring it) Oh, you're warm... put your arms  around me.
The STAR MAN does and Jenny jumps as the wet sleeves touc her back.
Take your shirt off.

It is difficult with Jenny around his waist, but he manag He drapes his arms over her. She snuggles into him. The R POUNDS ON THE ROOF. Gradually, Jenny responds to the STAR MAN's warmth and relaxes. She lifts her head off his ches and looks at him.
What?
Nothing.

She brushes her lips against his. The STAR MAN's not sure what's happening. But he's not offended. Her next kiss is full and long. He accepts it with his eyes open and when eases back he leans in for more. Jenny responds. As if on command, the satel compass comes from around behind the S MAN to hover in back of Jenny. He takes it between his pa and extinguishes it.

Jenny awakens and looks around. The STAR MAN is not with  her. As she stands up she hears his VOICE OUTSIDE. He is  speaking to something in his language. She goes to the door to find out what and sees him standi beside a fenced-in pasture talking to the horses inside.
Jenny joins the STAR MAN at the fence.
Good morning.
Horses.
You don't forget anything, do you?
No.
Jenny pets one of the horses on the nose.
(to the horse) Hello... hello. How are you this  morning?
Do they talk?!
(laughs) No, they don't talk... We talk to  them.
I understand.
An appaloosa nudges her way through the others to the fen
Oh, you're pretty...
I gave you a baby last night.
Shocked, Jenny looks at him from around the appaloosa's n The STAR MAN is combing a horse's mane with his fingers a he doesn't see her expression.
(meaning the horses) They are beautiful.
Yes, they are.
You have been very good to me,  Jennyhaydn. (turns to face her) You said you wanted a baby, so I  gave you one.
(shakes her head 'no') But...

It will be human and it will look  like this. (touches his face) But when it comes it will know  everything I know and everything you  know. That is something from my planet  that I want your baby to have.
I told you it's impossible for me to  have a baby.
You will have this baby. If you want  it. If you don't, I can stop it now.
Jenny comes over and puts her arms around the STAR MAN.
I want it.

A formation of six black Bell Cobra helicopters rush at u out of the blue. From above them we can see that they are heading for a small desert town. 'Welcome to Lathrop Well is spelled out on a hillside in white-washed stones.

Grubby, unshaven and unwashed, Shermin, Bell, Lyman and t rest of the crew watch the seven Cobras land in sequence. Fox, immaculate in a freshly pressed black flight suit, c out of the first one down and he and Shermin meet in the  middle of the runway.
Hello George.
Shermin...
What's all this for?
We have a new directive. I'm taking  over.
(scans the Cobras) We don't have to do it that way. We  can catch him this time.
Washington thinks it's too late for  that.
I've never been taken off an  assignment in my life. Give me twenty- four hours and I'll have him for  you.
You're not hearing me.

You can change a directive, George.  You've done it before. Listen to me.  He's going somewhere in Death Valley.  Lathrop Wells was never anything but  a bus stop. East is the nuclear site.  There are no roads in there. She was  teaching him to hitchhike. I'm telling  you. We block the four roads into  Death Valley and we got him.
We'll do that. But how are we going  to hold him? He can change himself  into a man. He can disappear.
That's the chance we have to take.
No, we don't.
Then you're going to have to do it  without me.
You're a career intelligence officer,  Shermin. You'll be in the air with  us.
You're talking about taking a life.  The most unique life form on this  planet. I think we're better than  that.

A fire-engine-red Pontiac convertible with two COWBOYS (l fifties) in the front and Jenny and the STAR MAN in the b moves with the traffic along the main drag in the downtow area. The STAR MAN's head swivels from side to side tryin to take in the neon that juts up around him. The converti stops at a light. The cowboy on the passenger side opens door and tips his hat to Jenny as she and the Star Man ge out of the back seat.
The STAR MAN is afraid of the crush of people and wants t stay close to Jenny, but is fascinated by the whir and cl and jingle of the one-armed bandits that seem to be  everywhere.
Is this gambling?

Jenny nods. A LADY in curlers and pedal pushers hits a tw dollar jackpot. Hanging onto Jenny's hand the STAR MAN tu around and walks sideways to watch the quarters tumble ou into the lady's shopping bag.
The cowboys were right. You can make  money fast gambling.
You don't make money gambling. You  lose it.

The STAR MAN hangs back to examine a one-armed bandit ins the front door while Jenny goes to the counter. An almost imperceptible blue haze seems to seep from under the STAR MAN's palms as he runs his hands up and down the sides of the machine.
(to the clerk) Do you have a good map of Death  Valley?
We should have. Let me see.
While the clerk searches for the map the STAR MAN comes u to Jenny.
May I have twenty-five cents, please?
What for?
I want to gamble.
Jenny sighs and rolls her eyes and fishes two quarters ou of her purse and hands them to him.
Here are two quarters. When you lose  these, you're not going to get  anymore.
I understand. (heading back to the  machine) Thank you.

He drops a quarter into the slot and pulls the handle. Wh the pictures of fruit spin behind the view window, his ha stroke the sides of the machine. An orange, a pear and a  cherry stop in the view window. At the counter Jenny expl to the clerk that she is hitchhiking and wants the busies route into Death Valley without going through Lathrop Wel The STAR MAN looks long and hard at the machine before pu in his last quarter. He pulls the handle. The blue haze f from his palms, three cherries lock into a line and the o armed bandit begins to spit quarters.

Jenny is nervous about being here. She feels every face t looks at them could be a cop. The STAR MAN is pulling her through a Maginot Line of slot machines toward a 'Super  Jackpot' machine that advertises a $275,000 payoff.
This is crazy. We don't have time  for this.
I know how to gamble now.
You won ten dollars. Big deal. If we  don't get a good ride before dark we  could miss your ship.
I want to get money for you and the  baby.
I don't need any money for the baby.  I'll be fine.
Inflation, tuition, college. Children  are damned expensive. I know.
The cook again?
(stepping up to the  'Super Jackpot') Yes.
If I ever run into that guy, I'm  going to kick his ass.

The STAR MAN pops a gleaming silver dollar into the machi pulls the handle and places his hands against the metal.  Jenny, knowing it can't work, but hoping that it will, st back and gnaws on her thumb. Then she sees the blue haze  vibrating out of the STAR MAN's palms. Jenny stifles a sc She looks around to see if anybody else has noticed. They haven't. The STAR MAN smiles at her. The force field does it's work. A picket line of 7's fills the view window. Am the jangle of bells and flashing lights that accompany a  winner Jenny doesn't know whether she should jump for joy hide her face.
A dot in the distance becomes a brand new Camaro. As it b away from under us we see a paper license in its back win The cabin light is on inside the car.

In the passenger seat the STAR MAN is riffling through a  Columbia "History of the World." A Webster's Dictionary i on the dash in front of him. Wedged between his legs and transmission well is a shopping bag full of money.
It'll tell you pretty much everything  about us...
This is very interesting. We are  born knowing our history. We have  other books. But not a book like  this.
Any words you don't know you can  find in the dictionary.
I understand.
It'll give you the different  countries, how they came to be, what  they are now, how America came to  be, the governments, the languages...  everything.
(chuckles) Many of my people will not believe  those things are possible. On my  planet there is only one government,  one people, one language. I will be  asked a lot of questions.
What will you say about us?
I will say that we can be friends.
We can.
She notices the green ring on her left hand and takes it  off.
This is yours...
If you want to keep it, you can.
I'd like to...
She slips it back on her finger above her wedding band. T drive in silence. The STAR MAN sets the history book on t dash.
(takes the ring off  again) Would you put some of your singing  in this for the baby?
You want the baby to laugh at me.
Yes.
With the STAR MAN SINGING IN HIS LANGUAGE, the Camaro mov further into Death Valley. The SONG FADES and we:
The Camaro blows by a gas station, closed for the night.
The STAR MAN shifts restlessly in his seat as he searches the ghostly landscape for something familiar. He activate the satel compass. The red and green dots are touching.
How long will it take you to get  home?
(absently) Many, many days and nights...
He presses the satel compass into his palms.
Would you like to listen to some  music?
The STAR MAN shakes his head "no."
I'm sure we could find a country and  western station.
No, thank you.
Jenny takes his hand in hers.
Don't worry. Everything's going to  be fine.
The STAR MAN smiles wanly at her.
(leans forward to  look up at night sky) Which star is yours?
It only takes the STAR MAN an instant to find his home.
There.
Where?
He directs Jenny's attention to the constellation Auriga.
(meaning the star  Capella) The yellow one.
Oh, wow... I'll tell you what. When  the baby is born, we'll go out in my  back yard and wave to you.
(smiles) I will wave to you.
All we can HEAR are the TIRES HUMMING over the road. The  Camaro rounds the side of a low hill.
Oh, shit!
Jenny slams on the brakes. One of the Cobra helicopters, from the inside, is parked next to a line of flares acros the road ahead.

The STAR MAN is looking through a window at the repair ba lit by a work light. Jenny is standing in a phone shell o the front of the garage, the receiver to her ear. The STAR MAN moves to the office door. He tries the knob. is locked.
(to the STAR MAN) They're trying to get him.
Suddenly the STAR MAN slams his shoulder against the door It swings open.
What are you doing?!!
Fox's voice comes out of the receiver in her hand.
Mrs. Haydn...
(speaking into a  headset) This is George Fox...
I want to speak to Marc Shermin.
You can speak to me, Mrs. Haydn. I'm  in charge of this operation now.
If I don't speak to Mr. Shermin, I'm  hanging up.
(a beat) Okay...
Tethered by the phone cord, Jenny tries to see what the S MAN is doing inside the repair bay.

Using an air filter top as a basket, the STAR MAN scaveng from the work bench and the car up on the lift, fuses, le of wire, circuit boards from a radio, tubing, metal pipe a Black and Decker drill. While he is doing this we get  glimpses of Jenny pleading his case on the phone. Finally leaving the receiver dangling at the end of its cord, she comes around to stand in the doorway.
Mr. Shermin wants to speak to you.
Here he is.
Shermin looks warily at the headset. When the STAR MAN do speak immediately, he takes the initiative.
Hello...
I must get to my ship, Mr. Shermin.
We can't let you do that.
I don't want to hurt anybody. I just  want to go home.
Fox is listening to the conversation.
All the roads into Death Valley are  blocked. We'd like to talk to you.
If I talk to you, I will miss my  ship.
Hold on a minute... Let's take the  chance, George.
No deal.
I'm afraid we can't let you go.
I understand.
He hangs up.

The STAR MAN shaves the rubber off the electrical lines  leading into the fuse box and clips two wires of his own  onto the exposed copper. With Jenny watching we have a mo of the STAR MAN working through the night: modifying the  insides of the Black and Decker drill, cutting out the mi section above the trigger, fitting electrical components  into that area, screwing a pipe into the bit-clamp, weldi it together with the spark that arcs between the electric wires.

Jenny folds a sheaf of money into a sheet of yellow paper and props it on the cash register. 'For Damages. Thank Yo is scribbled on the front. She runs out to catch the STAR MAN who is on his way to the Camaro.
Carrying the modified Black and Decker drill the STAR MAN opens the driver's door.
Where do you think you're going?
Thank you, Jennyhaydn. You are good.  I must go alone now.
I said I would get you to your ship  and that's where we're going to say  goodbye.

Both hands on the wheel, Jenny is burning down the center line. The STAR MAN bends two thin wires trailing out from the grip of the drill. Jenny winces as he buries them int the flesh on either side of his left wrist. The car skate around the corner of a low hill. They can see that the Co is still sitting next to the road.
(glancing at the  modified drill) I hope that works.

The STAR MAN is lost in concentration. Jenny kills her lights and glues the accelerator to the f Three MEN scramble from the helicopter with M16s. A BURST SLUGS RIPS THROUGH the Camaro's WINDSHIELD. The STAR MAN  leans out the passenger window and with an other-worldly  scream, fires. The helicopter is BLOWN TO SMITHEREENS. Th concussion throws the men to the ground.
The Camaro whizzes through the falling DEBRIS.
It works.
The STAR MAN slumps in exhaustion and pain.
I do not know how many times I can  do this.
It is filled with the radio voices of the Cobra crews set up to attack the Camaro.
The Camaro becomes airborne at the crest of a dip. Only i new shocks save the landing.

The STAR MAN draws the satel compass out between his palm The green dot now covers the right half of the red dot. H presses his palms together and looks past Jenny at the ru foothills. The first light of day is starting to color the sky behin them. Jenny and the STAR MAN are startled by the DRUMMING WHOMP OF A HELICOPTER. The STAR MAN looks out the window its source. He can't see anything. The SOUND FADES. In a  moment, it is REPEATED ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THE CAR and A IT FADES.
If my ship is not here, we are in  trouble.
This is a truism that Jenny doesn't want to hear and she  flexes her fingers on the wheel.
(points at a  distinctive cone  peak) That's where we landed last time.  Right under that mountain.

Jenny and the STAR MAN steady themselves for the last leg their journey. Suddenly, their silence is exploded by a C dropping out of the sky in front of them. Its searchlight bangs into their faces and, with its thirty-calibre MACHI GUNS BLAZING, it comes straight at them. Jenny yanks the Camaro onto the shoulder. The SLUGS CHEW the asphalt beside it. She fishtails back onto the road. SECOND COBRA surprises them from the STAR MAN's side. Its MACHINE GUN KNOCKS OUT the BACK WINDOW before he can FIRE The STAR MAN crawls over his seat and arranges himself in the hole that was the back window to meet the Cobras' nex FIRING RUN. It doesn't take them long. The first two have been joined by a THIRD. They swoop down on the Camaro.
The gunsights lock on the car below. The CO-PILOT squeeze the trigger.

SHOTS THUMP INTO the trunk in front of the STAR MAN and h FIRES. The lead HELICOPTER ERUPTS, raining pieces of hot  metal over the desert floor. The other helicopters are ja out of their run and their BULLETS harmlessly KICK UP SAN on the shoulder. Before they can regroup, the STAR MAN BL THEM OUT OF THE SKY.
In front!!! In front!!!

The STAR MAN has to hang on as Jenny dodges the car out o the path of a Cobra skimming over the highway toward them As it goes over, he is able to get off a SHOT directly IN its UNDERBELLY. The BALL OF FLAME almost engulfs the Cama
The STAR MAN slumps down into the back seat breathing har Jenny looks over her shoulder at him and is shocked at th strain that shows on his face.
Hang on.
She throws the car into a skid and leaves the blacktop fo dirt road winding between two low hills.
At the base of a sandstone cliff, the Camaro slides to a  stop. Jenny helps the STAR MAN out. She supports him as t struggle toward the protection of the boulders. Fox's Cob roars over the hill.
(spots the car) Over there.

The STAR MAN turns toward the Cobra. Weakly, he raises hi weapon and pulls the trigger. Nothing happens. The search from the Cobra finds them. Its machine guns begin to rais puffs of gravel around them. Jenny grabs the STAR MAN's a and pulls him into the relative safety of the rocks. The  STAR MAN collapses against the cool stone.
(gasps) I can't shoot anymore.

Jenny looks out between the crags. Shermin's helicopter  arrives to join the Cobra. With their searchlights flicki over the sagebrush, they move cautiously toward the cliff Jenny turns back to the STAR MAN. He is too weak to run  anymore.
(touches his shoulder  lightly) I won't let anyone hurt you.
Watch it. They're coming out.
Six images (close-up to full shot) of Jenny and the STAR stepping out of their hiding place fill the television sc in front of Shermin.
End it, Shermin.
Lyman taps his keyboard. The screens all change to a long shot of Jenny and the STAR MAN with cross-hairs superimpo on them.
Shermin's helicopter moves toward Jenny and the STAR MAN  standing helpless in the circle thrown by the searchlight
The cross-hairs have locked on Jenny and the STAR MAN. Sh knows he can't do it. He picks up a headset.
George... Do you hear me, George?
What?
I just retired.
Shermin!! Shermin!!!
Shermin flips a switch on the console that cuts Fox off.
(to his crew) Let's get out of here.
Shermin's helicopter passes over the heads of Jenny and t STAR MAN and rises into the dawn sky.
Shermin!!!
He throws down his headset.
(to the pilot) Lock in.

The gunsights lock in on Jenny and the STAR MAN. Fox's gr tightens on the trigger. Suddenly the helicopter begins t vibrate and drift off its target. Fox looks toward the so coming from his right and his eyes widen in fear as he se the STAR MAN's ship looming over him.

The spacecraft passes over the top of the helicopter. The whirling downdraft emanating from the spaceship's underbe yanks the Cobra away from Jenny and the STAR MAN and whip it into a spin which gets faster and faster until it  disintegrates and falls to the desert floor.

Jenny and the STAR MAN shield their faces against the DUS STORM that billows under the WHINING DESCENT of the  spacecraft. It settles into a landing across the dirt roa resting on its three pods. With a crack, a cone of bright white light blasts from the underside.
Well...
I must go.
Jenny nods.
What do I do now?
You say you love me and kiss me  'goodbye.'
The STAR MAN puts his arms around her and holds her tight
I love you.
(her head on his  shoulder) I'm never going to see you again, am  I?
No.
He kisses the tears out of her eyes, then full on the mou
I love you.
The STAR MAN steps back and places a hand on Jenny's stom
Tell the baby about me.
I will.
Goodbye.
He turns from her and walks to his ship. Jenny watches hi go, then remembers something.
Wait!!
She gets the Webster's Dictionary and the Columbia Histor of the World from the Camaro and runs to the STAR MAN. He takes them and kisses her again.
Thank you, Jennyhaydn.
Jenny backs away as the STAR MAN walks under the ship int the white light. He waves one last time to Jenny and is  swallowed into the ship by the light.

Jenny turns away from the stinging sand as the space-craf lifts off. When she looks again, it is high and moving ov the foothills. A banking turn brings it back. The ship di low over her, rocks itself in a gesture of farewell, then shoots off into the stars. When she can no longer see it, Jenny drops her wave with a sigh and starts back toward t Camaro. Over her walk, we SUPER:

head_text.subj: JENNY HAYDN GAVE BIRTH TO AN EIGHT-POUND, SEVEN-OUNCE BAB
